tossups.question: The speaker of this poem advises that although “The all-beholding sun shall see no more,” the “patriarchs of the infant world” form “one mighty sepulchre.” This poem describes how “thine individual being” will “be a brother to the insensible rock.” The command “Take the wings / Of morning, pierce the Barcan wilderness” is given “To him who in the love of (*) Nature holds/ Communion with her visible forms.” This poem concludes by advising the reader to “approach thy grave, / Like one who [...] lies down to pleasant dreams." For 10 points, name this poem titled for a meditation on death, written by William Cullen Bryant.

After reading Greek epitaphs off of crosses in this novel, a vision of a tropical swampland convinces a writer to go abroad. This novel’s protagonist sees “Eros, with the… bloom of Parian marble” in a hotel lobby and imagines himself as Socrates instructing Phaedrus. A old man’s brown wig and rouged cheeks disgust this novel’s protagonist, who recognizes the smell of (*) germicide in the street. This novel’s protagonist collapses after eating overripe strawberries while obsessing over the Polish boy Tadzio (“TAH-joe”). For 10 points, name this novella by Thomas Mann which ends when Gustav von Aschenbach succumbs to cholera while vacationing in the title city.
tossups.answer: Death in Venice [or Der Tod in Venedig]

tossups.question: The line "green, how I want you green" is repeated in this author's poem "Sleepwalking Romance." This author wrote a poem in which the speaker repeats “I will not see it!” after the title character’s death which took place “at five in the afternoon.” Adela has an affair with Pepe el Romano before the title (*) matriarch shoots him in a play by this author. This author was assassinated by pro-Franco forces for his socialist views. For 10 points, name this Spanish poet of “Lament for the Death of a Bullfighter” who also wrote the play The House of Bernarda Alba.

Ikeda Sen led a group of 200 women who used these objects. Teppo were ashigaru who specialized in the use of these objects. The island of Tanegashima lends its name to an early design of these objects, which the swordsmith Yaita struggled to add screw holes into at first. Oda Nobunaga’s fondness of these objects led him to strategically employ them at the (*) Battle of Nagashino, helping him defeat the powerful Takeda clan. A Joseon official wrote that these objects allowed Japan to rapidly invade Korea at first, noting “bows and arrows could not compare.” For 10 points, name these weapons that use an explosive black powder.
tossups.answer: guns [accept clear equivalents like firearms, accept arquebus, accept muskets, accept answers like pistols or rifles, but do not accept answers specifically referring to later firearms like “revolvers” or “machine guns”, accept Tanegashima before read]
tossups.answer_formatted: guns [accept clear equivalents like firearms, or arquebus, or muskets, or answers like pistols or rifles, but do not or answers specifically referring to later firearms like “revolvers or machine guns”, or Tanegashima before read]
acceptable: answers specifically referring to later firearms like “revolvers

tossups.question: The Avro Arrow was a planned supersonic fighter jet for this country’s air force. The Sikh extremist group Babbar Khalsa bombed Air India Flight 182 as it left this country. Bombardier is an airplane manufacturer in this country, whose aforementioned Avro Arrow was cancelled by prime minister John (*) Diefenbaker. This country launched Operation Yellow Ribbon to handle a flux of diverted flights, with many of the stranded passengers being housed in towns like Gander in Newfoundland and Labrador. For 10 points, name this country that grounded several flights while their southern neighbor experienced the 9/11 attacks.

On this continent, the Onyx River feeds into the highly saline Lake Vanda, while the Don Juan Pond is fed from deep groundwater. Both lakes are located in this continent’s Dry Valleys. Overlapping shield volcanoes make up the Adare peninsula on this continent. Four volcanoes form an island on this continent named after its discoverer Sir James (*) Ross. This continent contains many subglacial lakes, such as Lake Vostok. Glaciers are studied at the Amundsen-Scott research station on, for 10 points, what least-populated continent, located at the South Pole?

After Henry Greene and Robert Juet committed a mutiny on one vessel led by this man, fellow mutineer Abacuk Pricket was acquitted for his role in saving this man’s ship. During his time aboard the Hopewell, this man reached Novaya Zemlya under his commission by the English Muscovy company. While traveling aboard the (*) Half-moon, this man sailed up a river that he deemed too narrow and shallow to cross; that river was later named after him. For 10 points, name this British explorer who claimed New Netherland for the Dutch and is the namesake of the river separating New York City from New Jersey.

In a novel by this author, the title character lives in a hut on the Visagie farm before he is taken to a rehabilitation camp. In another novel by this author, the protagonist disposes of euthanized animals while working at Bev Shaw’s animal shelter. A harelipped gardener creates a rickshaw to transport his (*) mother’s ashes in a novel by this author. The protagonist of a novel by this author is fired for having an affair with the student Melanie Isaacs. That novel by this author centers on the former professor David Lurie. For 10 points, name this 2003 Nobel Literature laureate, the South African author of the novels Life & Times of Michael K and Disgrace.

bonuses.leadin: This phrase was first coined by Dwight D. Eisenhower in his 1961 Farewell Address, in which he derided its “unwarranted influence.” For 10 points each:
answers: military-industrial complex [accept military-industry complex, or MIC]
parts: Name this three-word phrase describing an “alliance” between America’s defense sector and companies that prop it up. It is often invoked when discussing how businesses profit from war.

A key feature of the military-industrial complex is the close relationship between the Department of Defense and large private military contractors, including this largest one that built the SR-71 and U2 planes.

An early warning against the military-industrial complex was the book “War Is a Racket” by retired General Smedley Butler. In the book, he describes making “Mexico, especially Tampoco, safe for” American interests in this resource and ensuring John D. Rockefeller’s company built on this resource went “unmolested” in “China.”

bonuses.leadin: Opponents of this movement such as Charles Chauncy caused a schism between the “old lights” and “new lights.” For 10 points each:
answers: First Great Awakening [prompt on Great Awakening; do not accept "Second Great Awakening"]
slaves [prompt on African-Americans or Black people]
parts: Name this large religious revival in early to mid-eighteenth century America. The name for the new lights came from a sermon by this movement's preacher Jonathan Edwards.

Virginia clergyman Samuel Davies advocated for the evangelism of these people during the First Great Awakening. These people incorporated Christian beliefs into spirituals as "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot."
This First Great Awakening preacher and advocate of better treatment for slaves lobbied the Georgia colonial government to legalize slavery in order to staff his Bethesda Orphanage with slaves.
answers_formatted: First Great Awakening [prompt on Great Awakening; do not accept "Second Great Awakening"]
